docs.lead_paragraph: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.
docs.abstract: In this lesson, students examine current and past economic crises around the world, using the current recession in the United States as a starting point.
docs.snippet: In this lesson, students examine current and past economic crises around the world, using the current recession in the United States as a starting point.

byline.original: By ANNISSA HAMBOUZ and JAVAID KHAN

docs.lead_paragraph: Oxford Health Plans, one of the biggest health insurers in the New York area, has paid Caremark Rx $20 million to end a contract to provide mail-order prescription-drug services to its 1.5 million plan members. Caremark will supply specialty biotechnology products to Oxford members through Sept. 12, 2004, as part of the settlement, Caremark's chief financial officer, Howard McLure, said. Oxford signed a five-year agreement with Merck's Medco unit in October to manage its pharmacy benefits, replacing existing contracts with Caremark and another rival, Express Scripts Inc.

headline.main: OXFORD HEALTH PLANS PAYS $20 MILLION TO END CONTRACT

docs.abstract: Oxford Health Plans pays Caremark Rx $20 million to terminate contract to provide mail-order prescription-drug services to its 1.5 million plan members; has signed 5-year agreement with Merck's Medco division to manage its pharmaceutical benefits, replacing Caremark and Express Scripts Inc (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Republicans in the Senate said today that they would support a new idea for giving the economy an immediate boost -- freeing employers and employees from paying Social Security payroll taxes for one month -- in an effort to break a partisan impasse over the proposed economic stimulus package. The plan would amount to a tax cut, split evenly between workers and employers, worth $38 billion if it were enacted in December, or about $43 billion if put in place early next year. For a worker earning $40,000 a year, the payroll tax holiday would mean an extra $207. The worker's employer would save the same amount.

headline.kicker: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE RECOVERY PACKAGE

docs.abstract: Republicans in Senate offer $100 billion package of tax cuts in 2002 in bid to spur economy, including plan to free employers and employees from paying Social Security payroll taxes for month; Social Security plan would be worth $38 billion if enacted in Dec, or about $43 billion if put in place early in 2002; package would also speed cut in personal income tax rate to 25 percent and provide tax breaks for business; Democrats say they are open to payroll tax hiatus, but want deal linked to added spending for domestic security (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: As early as 1990, when AIDS was almost unknown in South Africa, there was one man in the Hlabisa Health District who saw the rising dust of the epidemic over the horizon and tried to stop it. Instead, he found himself cast as a a voice crying in the wilderness. At one point, he was quite literally that -- a white, Zulu-speaking great-grandson of a Danish missionary, tramping through a drought-stricken landscape with a spear and a club, beset by hyenas and thieves, in a stunt to get the attention of the Zulu king.

headline.main: A Lonely Crusade Warning Africans of AIDS

docs.lead_paragraph: It was like a story from old New York, something O. Henry might have written, about a young artist, struggling in the city's shadows, whose true love brings him a sudden burst of good luck. Kurt Wenzel had hardly ever read a novel in his life. He was a great baseball player at his high school in Sayreville, N.J., with a 90-mile-an-hour fastball. There were even some feelers from the pros, and a baseball scholarship to Montclair State College. Then, he hurt his arm. No more baseball.

headline.main: Writing, And Living, The Lit Life

docs.abstract: Profile of and interview with Kurt Wenzel, whose novel Lit Life was published last summer to glowing reviews; book is roman a clef about literary world; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: It is another unhappy holiday season for Aaron M. Feuerstein, the widely admired New England mill owner whose textile company, Malden Mills, is again in crisis. After a December fire six years ago ravaged much of his factory in Lawrence, Mass., Mr. Feuerstein won plaudits for rebuilding the mill from top to bottom and for paying his idled workers for months. By the time the new factory -- which makes Polartec and Polarfleece, the warm, synthetic fabrics popular in outdoor clothing -- reopened nearly two years later, he had rehired most of his 2,700 employees. In an era of widespread corporate downsizing, his actions made Mr. Feuerstein a national icon of corporate sensitivity.

headline.main: Fire Could Not Stop A Mill, but Debts May

docs.abstract: Critics of Aaron M Feuerstein, owner of Malden Mills and formerly national icon of corporate sensitivity, suggest that his past benevolence helped bring company to its present state -- short on cash and $140 million in debt; emergency $25 million loan he now seeks is identical to cost he bore paying salaries to idled workers after 1995 fire destroyed mill facilities; building replacement mill for manufacturing Polartec and Polarfleece fabrics cost $430 million; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The group of economists that tracks business cycles made official today what has been apparent to laid-off workers and struggling businesses for months: the longest economic expansion on record gave way earlier this year to the first recession in a decade and the 10th since World War II. The group, the National Bureau of Economic Research's business-cycle dating committee, said the recession began in March, months before the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11 or the sharp rise in unemployment.

headline.main: Economists Make It Official: U.S. Is in Recession

docs.abstract: National Bureau of Economic Research concludes that US economy entered recession March; economists disagree about timing and strength of rebound that will follow, but consensus anticipates its start in first half of 2002 (M)
docs.snippet: The group of economists that tracks business cycles made official today what has been apparent to laid-off workers and struggling businesses for months: the longest economic expansion on record gave way earlier this year to the first recession in a...

docs.lead_paragraph: More than 450 registered nurses went on strike yesterday at St. Catherine of Siena Medical Center in Smithtown, Suffolk County. But hospital officials said the 273-bed center continued to operate normally, helped in large part by the hiring of 105 replacement nurses. The nurses walked out after talks broke down on Sunday over their union's demand to improve staffing levels and change the nurses' health plan.

headline.main: Nurses Strike at Hospital on Long Island

docs.abstract: More than 450 nurses go on strike at St Catherine of Siena Medical Center in Smithtown, NY; issues being contended are staffing levels and health plan; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Jean-Louis Palladin, a fearless and passionate cook who helped to free French cuisine in the United States from a hidebound orthodoxy while influencing a generation of chefs and food lovers, died yesterday in McLean, Va. He was 55. The cause of death was lung cancer, said Ann Brody, a spokeswoman for his family.

headline.main: Jean-Louis Palladin, 55, a French Chef With Verve, Dies

docs.abstract: Jean-Louis Palladin, influential chef who helped liberate French cuisine in America from rigorous orthodoxy, dies at age 55; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: IN her worst weeks, Wai Chun Ng at least had a $50 paycheck. After 40 years of sewing in Chinatown factories, job cuts had reduced Ms. Ng to working as a finisher, earning a penny for every two buttons she cut the thread on. Last month, when Ms. Ng finally lost her job, she turned to the Red Cross to help put food on the table for herself and her retired husband. Ms. Ng, a small, soft-spoken 61-year-old woman, told her story as she sat in the Chinatown office of Local 23-25, the union of Needletrades, Industrial and Textile Employees. Her words were interpreted by Lana Cheung, the local's education director.

headline.main: Their Demeanors Don't Betray The Desperation

docs.abstract: Felicia Lee Coping column on problems besetting many garment workers in New York City's Chinatown who have lost their jobs in wake of World Trade Center attacks; notes as many as 7,000 of 12,000 Chinatown garment workers are without work and most factories there are operating at less than 50 percent capacity; some qualify for disaster relief but others, those who work north of Canal Street, do not; drawing (M)
